VLIB Function Reference

Exponentially-Weighted Running Mean of a Video

Introduction and Use Cases

A background subtraction algorithm might consist of:
  1. Computing a representative statistic of the luma component for each pixel in a video.
  2. Labeling deviations from this statistic as foreground. One such statistic is the exponentially-weighted (EW) running mean.

Specification

Function

Updates the exponential running mean of the luma component of a video. If the foreground mask bit is set, indicating there is obstruction by a foreground object, the running mean will not be updated.

Variants

This functionality is available in two variants: 16-bit and 32-bit

Inputs


    Parameter              Description                              16-bit           32-bit
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
    *runningMean           EW running mean buffer to be updated    (SQ8.7)          (SQ8.23)
    *newLuma               Most recent luma buffer                 (UQ8.0)          (UQ8.0)
    *mask32packed          Foreground mask buffer                  (32-bit packed)  (32-bit packed)
     weight                Weight of the newest luma               (SQ0.15)         (SQ0.31)
     pixelCount            Number of pixels to process             (UQ32.0)         (UQ32.0)

Outputs

    Returns VLIB Error Status

Method

In the implementation shown in the equation below, the exponential running mean is updated for those pixels where the foreground mask is zero: 
    updatedMean = (1 - weight) x previousMean + weight x newestData

APIS

S16 Variant
  • VLIB_updateEWRMeanS16
  • VLIB_initMeanWithLumaS16

S32 Variant

  • VLIB_updateEWRMeanS32
  • VLIB_initMeanWithLumaS32

Notes

  • Adaptation Through Running Statistics - Over the course of a day, the illumination of an outdoor scene changes drastically. A background model needs to adapt to such effects and only report changes inherent to the scene, as opposed to its appearance. One practical approach is to compute the running (moving) statistics of the scene over a period of observation.

  • Foreground Objects - Based on inference or a priori knowledge, one could classify certain pixels of a video frame as foreground object (or outlier) and exclude them from the averaging operation. This mechanism would keep foreground object pixels from influencing the running mean of the background.

References

  1. Chapter 15: Moving Average Filters, in Digital Signal Processing: A Practical Guide for Engineers and Scientists, Steven W. Smith, 2002, ISBN 0-7506-7444.
  2. "Moving object recognition using an adaptive background memory" in Time-Varying Image Processing and Moving Object Recognition, K.P. Larmann and A. von Brandt, Elsevier Science Publishers B.V., 1990.
